awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: IDBR: TYPE A: Development of Squishy Robot  Hands for a Delicate, Effective and Non-Intrusive Approach to Studying  Deep Coral Reefs
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Harvard University and the City University of New York to develop a new instrument for delicate underwater deep sea manipulation of soft or fragile organisms. Deep coral reefs, and deep sea environments in general, are hotspots for unique biological diversity and genetic adaptions that have only recently become accessible to scientists due to advances in remotely operated vehicle and submersible technology. Yet, while there is increasing access to these environments, biological collection and the molecular biology and biochemical analysis of these environments is still highly challenging. One source of this challenge is the robotic collection arms currently used in these environments. Commercially-available deep sea manipulation systems are designed to perform heavy mechanical work (i.e., construction or pipeline maintenance) and are not geared to perform delicate tasks, such as the collection of fragile biological specimens. Details for the design and construction of this instrument will be made available to the public.  

The new instrument is based on soft robots and will enable unparalleled sampling in the deep sea environment. This new instrument will be mounted to remotely operated vehicles and will mimic the operator's arm and hand motions for quick, nimble, and delicate interactions. Feedback to the user, integration of soft structures at multiple scales, and the development of a hair-like feedback and actuator control system that will prevent damage to fragile samples are key aspects in this novel robotic arm. The non-traditional bilateral control software and underwater actuators are innovative, and the modular design with multiple grippers makes this system extremely flexible for wide range of biological sampling. The gripping surface will incorporate micro scale surface textures that minimize damage to delicate biological samples. The long term robustness of this instrument in such harsh deep sea environments is also an important feature. By sampling this mostly unknown environment the instrumentation will benefit the molecular and cellular biology, marine biology, and biochemistry research communities.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: Collaborative Research: IDBR: TYPE A: Development of Squishy Robot Hands for a Delicate, Effective and Non-Intrusive Approach to Studying Deep Coral Reefs

Director/PI: David Gruber

Awardee: CUNY Baruch College

Federal Award ID: 1556213

This project outcomes report describes the culmination of our efforts to create and deploy soft end-effectors and manipulator systems for delicate deep-sea manipulation and sampling. This has included the development of new soft robot hands, arms, and associated power and control infrastructure. These soft robots have been deployed around the world’s oceans, successfully sampling organisms that would elude the grasp of more traditional manipulators.

We have primarily focused our efforts on the development of soft graspers that consist of fluidic soft digits that interacted with objects based on the design of the finger structure, the finger materials, and the applied pressure. These soft robotic graspers have been deployed around the world’s oceans to interact with deep marine life in unprecedented ways. We have also extended this original concept of delicate soft hands even further, to grasp and manipulate gelatinous organisms including as jellyfish. This was all based on the hypothesis that lower contact pressures during manipulation interactions would result in less stress to the animal, relative to legacy rigid grasping and manipulation systems. We have published a paper (Tessler et al 2020) that describes the use of our gentle grasping techniques to quantify, for the first time, stress responses of animals being grasped via the soft gripper. This has been a fundamental tenet of our research, and this paper represents a major milestone. In the paper, our research team describes experimental results in which jellyfish were handled with soft grippers, as well as with rigid grippers. Using RNA transcriptomic analysis, the team showed that the jellyfish handled with the soft grippers express significantly less stress reactions. Research expeditions were conducted to test the underwater robotics on deep and mesophotic reefs highlighting their functionality and durability in diverse field conditions.

Associated Publications:

Teeple, C. B., Becker, K. P., & Wood, R. J. 2018. Soft Curvature and Contact Force Sensors for Deep-Sea Grasping via Soft Optical Waveguides. In IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems (pp. 1621–1627). Madrid, Spain. 

Phillips, B. T., Becker, K. P., Kurumaya, S., Galloway, K. C., Whittredge, G., Vogt, D. M. and Wood, R. J. 2018. A Dexterous, Glove-Based Teleoperable Low-Power Soft Robotic Arm for Delicate Deep-Sea Biological Exploration. Scientific Reports, 8(1):14779. 

Teoh, Z. E., Phillips, B. T., Becker, K. P., Whittredge, G., Weaver, J. C., Hoberman, C., … Wood, R. J. 2018. Rotary-actuated folding polyhedrons for midwater investigation of delicate marine organisms. Science Robotics, 3(20), eaat5276.

Vogt, D. M., Becker, K. P., Phillips, B. T., Graule, M. A., Rotjan, R. D., Shank, T. M., Gruber, D. F. 2018. Shipboard design and fabrication of custom 3D-printed soft robotic manipulators for the investigation of delicate deep-sea organisms. Plos One, 13(8): e0200386.

Sinatra, N. R., Teeple, C. B., Vogt, D. M., Parker, K. K., Gruber, D. F., & Wood, R. J. 2019. Ultragentle manipulation of delicate structures using a soft robotic gripper. Science Robotics, 4(33), eaax5425.

M. Tessler, M.R. Brugler, J.A. Burns, N.R. Sinatra, D.M. Vogt, A. Varma, M. Xiao, R.J. Wood, and D.F. Gruber. 2020. Ultra-gentle soft robotic fingers induce minimal transcriptomic response in a fragile marine animal, Current Biology, vol. 30, no. 4, pp. R157-R158,.

C.B. Teeple, T.N. Koutros, M.A. Graule, and R.J. Wood. 2020. Multi-segment soft robotic fingers enable robust precision grasping, Int. J. of Robotics Research, 39(14), 1647–1667.

K.P. Becker, C.B. Teeple, N. Charles, Y. Jung, D. Baum, J. Weaver, L. Mahadevan, and R.J. Wood. 2022. Active collective entanglement enables grasping, PNAS, 119 (42) e2209819119/

Gruber, D.F. and R.J Wood. 2022. Advances and future outlooks in soft robotics for minimally invasive marine biology. Science Robotics 7(66):eabm6807.

Burns JA, Becker KP, Casagrande D, Daniels J, Roberts P, Orenstein E, Vogt DM, Zhi Ern Teoh, Wood R, Yin AH, Genot B, Gruber DF, Katija K, Wood RJ, Phillips, BT. 2024. An in situ digital synthesis strategy for the discovery and description of ocean life, Science Advances, 10.1126/sciadv.adj4960

Modified by: David Gruber

This has included the development of new soft robot hands, arms, and associated power and control infrastructure. These soft robots have been deployed around the worlds oceans, successfully sampling organisms that would elude the grasp of more traditional manipulators.


We have primarily focused our efforts on the development of soft graspers that consist of fluidic soft digits that interacted with objects based on the design of the finger structure, the finger materials, and the applied pressure. These soft robotic graspers have been deployed around the worlds oceans to interact with deep marine life in unprecedented ways.
